dublin_core.dcvalue: OBJECTIVE To study the effect of fast reporting by mobile phone short message service SMS on anxiety levels in women undergoing prenatal biochemical screening for Down syndrome METHOD From January 2005 to December 2006 2782 women undergoing prenatal biochemical serum screening were randomized into fast reporting by SMS group A or without mobile phone reporting group B Anxiety levels were measured with the Spielberger State Trait Anxiety Inventory STAI before prenatal screen testing before the appointed clinic when the SMS report had already been given to group A and 3 days after the appointed clinic when the full screening report had been given to groups A and B RESULTS For screen negative women anxiety scores did not differ between groups before prenatal screen testing and 3 days after the appointed clinic The state anxiety scores measured on the second occasion had declined significantly in group A The state anxiety scores in both groups increased over the 3 week period after being informed of positive screen results The trait and state anxiety scores at all points did not differ between the two groups of screen positive women CONCLUSIONS The provision of a routine reporting system plus additional SMS report revealed some overall benefits in reducing anxiety among women with screen negative result
Anxiety levels in women undergoing prenatal maternal serum screening for Down syndrome: the effect of a fast reporting system by mobile phone short-message service.
